skills.name: Acrobatics
skills.description: Your Dexterity (Acrobatics) check covers your attempt to stay on your feet in a tricky situation, such as when you're trying to run across a sheet of ice, balance on a tightrope, or stay upright on a rocking ship's deck. The GM might also call for a Dexterity (Acrobatics) check to see if you can perform acrobatic stunts, including dives, rolls, somersaults, and flips.

skills.name: Animal Handling
skills.description: When there is any question whether you can calm down a domesticated animal, keep a mount from getting spooked, or intuit an animal's intentions, the GM might call for a Wisdom (Animal Handling) check. You also make a Wisdom (Animal Handling) check to control your mount when you attempt a risky maneuver.

skills.name: Arcana
skills.description: Your Intelligence (Arcana) check measures your ability to recall lore about spells, magic items, eldritch symbols, magical traditions, the planes of existence, and the inhabitants of those planes.

skills.name: Athletics
skills.description: Your Strength (Athletics) check covers difficult situations you encounter while climbing, jumping, or swimming
examples: You attempt to climb a sheer or slippery cliff, avoid hazards while scaling a wall, or cling to a surface while something is trying to knock you off.
You try to jump an unusually long distance or pull off a stunt midjump.

You struggle to swim or stay afloat in treacherous currents, storm-tossed waves, or areas of thick seaweed. Or another creature tries to push or pull you underwater or otherwise interfere with your swimming.

skills.name: Deception
skills.description: Your Charisma (Deception) check determines whether you can convincingly hide the truth, either verbally or through your actions. This deception can encompass everything from misleading others through ambiguity to telling outright lies.
examples: Trying to fast-talk a guard.
Trying to con a merchant.
Try to earn money through gambling.
Try to pass yourself off in a disguise.
Try to dull someone's suspicions with false assurances.
Try to maintain a straight face while telling a blatant lie.

skills.name: History
skills.description: Your Intelligence (Arcana) check measures your ability to recall lore about spells, magic items, eldritch symbols, magical traditions, the planes of existence, and the inhabitants of those planes.

skills.name: Insight
skills.description: Your Wisdom (Insight) check decides whether you can determine the true intentions of a creature, such as when searching out a lie or predicting someone's next move. Doing so involves gleaning clues from body language, speech habits, and changes in mannerisms.

skills.name: Intimidation
skills.description: When you attempt to influence someone through overt threats, hostile actions, and physical violence, the GM might ask you to make a Charisma (Intimidation) check.
examples: Trying to pry information out of a prisoner.
Trying to convince street thugs to back down from a confrontation.
Trying to use the edge of a broken bottle to convince a sneering vizier to reconsider a decision.

skills.name: Investigation
skills.description: When you look around for clues and make deductions based on those clues, you make an Intelligence (Investigation) check.
examples: You try to deduce the location of a hidden object.
You try to discern from the appearance of a wound what kind of weapon dealt it.
You try to determine the weakest point in a tunnel that could cause it to collapse.
Poring through ancient scrolls in search of a hidden fragment of knowledge might also call for an Intelligence (Investigation) check.

skills.name: Medicine
skills.description: A Wisdom (Medicine) check lets you try to stabilize a dying companion or diagnose an illness.

skills.name: Nature
skills.description: Your Intelligence (Nature) check measures your ability to recall lore about terrain, plants and animals, the weather, and natural cycles.

skills.name: Percepption
skills.description: Your Wisdom (Perception) check lets you spot, hear, or otherwise detect the presence of something. It measures your general awareness of your surroundings and the keenness of your senses.
examples: You try to hear a conversation through a closed door.
You try to eavesdrop under an open window.
You try to hear monsters moving stealthily in the forest.
You try to spot things that are obscured or easy to miss, whether they are orcs lying in ambush on a road, thugs hiding in the shadows of an alley, or candlelight under a closed secret door.

skills.name: Preformance
skills.description: Your Charisma (Performance) check determines how well you can delight an audience with music, dance, acting, storytelling, or some other form of entertainment.

skills.name: Persuasion
skills.description: When you attempt to influence someone or a group of people with tact, social graces, or good nature, the GM might ask you to make a Charisma (Persuasion) check. Typically, you use persuasion when acting in good faith, to foster friendships, make cordial requests, or exhibit proper etiquette.
examples: Trying to convince a chamberlain to let your party see the king.
Trying to negotiate peace between warring tribes.
Trying to inspire a crowd of townsfolk.

skills.name: Religion
skills.description: Your Intelligence (Nature) check measures your ability to recall lore about terrain, plants and animals, the weather, and natural cycles.

skills.name: Sleight of Hand
skills.description: Whenever you attempt an act of legerdemain or manual trickery, such as planting something on someone else or concealing an object on your person, make a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check. The GM might also call for a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check to determine whether you can lift a coin purse off another person or slip something out of another person's pocket.

skills.name: Stealth
skills.description: Make a Dexterity (Stealth) check when you attempt to conceal yourself from enemies, slink past guards, slip away without being noticed, or sneak up on someone without being seen or heard.

skills.name: Survival
skills.description: The GM might ask you to make a Wisdom (Survival) check to follow tracks, hunt wild game, guide your group through frozen wastelands, identify signs that owlbears live nearby, predict the weather, or avoid quicksand and other natural hazards.
